tit.e: Ikai (the court rank)
Ikai (the court rank)
Ikai (the court rank)

sen.j: 位階（いかい）とは官吏の序列をいう。
sen.e: "Ikai" (the court rank) is a ranking system of the government officials.
"Ikai" (the court rank) is a ranking system of the government officials.
"Ikai" (the court rank) is a ranking system of the government officials.

sen.j: 日本では勲等と並び位階勲等と称され、主に律令法（律令制）によって定められたものを指す(主に明治時代から昭和前期までは金鵄勲章功級も含まれた)。
sen.e: Combined with "Kunto," it was also called "Ikai Kunto" (the court rank and honors) in Japan, and generally referred to what was stipulated by the Ritsuryo codes (the Ritsuryo system). (Particularlly from the Meiji to the early Showa periods, the Order of the Golden Kite was included.)

Combined with "Kunto," it was also called "Ikai Kunto" (the court rank and honors) in Japan, and generally referred to what was stipulated by the Ritsuryo codes (the Ritsuryo system). (Particularlly from the Meiji to the early Showa periods, the Order of the Golden Kite was included.)

Combined with Kunto (order of merit) it was also called "Ikai Kunto" in Japan, and generally referred to what was stipulated by the Ritsuryo codes (the Ritsuryo System, a system of centralized government based on the ritsuryo code). (Particularlly from the Meiji to the early Showa periods, the Order of the Golden Kite was included.)
sen.cmt: 勲等の説明補足Ikai kunto の後の説明は既に出ているので削除律令制の説明補足

sen.j: 律令制下の位階制においては、親王に対する位階は品位 (日本史)として別途4階が定められた。
sen.e: In the court rank system under the Ritsuryo system, four ranks called "Honi" (the history of Japan) were seperately set up for the court rank to the Imperial princes.
In the court rank system under the Ritsuryo system, four ranks called "Honi" (the history of Japan) were seperately set up for the court rank to the Imperial princes.
In the court rank system under the Ritsuryo system, four ranks called Honi (court rank) (the history of Japan) were separately set up for the court rank to the Imperial princes.

sen.j: 位階は主に王 (皇族)および人臣が対象であり、人臣の位階については律令法が廃止された明治時代以降は、官吏であった者や特に功績のあった者などに与えられる栄典の一つとなった。
sen.e: The court rank was designed mainly for princes without the title of "Shinno"(Prince of the blood), members of the Imperial family, and their subjects, but after the Meiji period in which the Ritsuryo codes were abolished, the court rank became a rank of honor which was bestowed upon those who had been government officials or those who had performed significant services.

The court rank was designed mainly for princes without the title of "Shinno"(Prince of the blood), members of the Imperial family, and their subjects, but after the Meiji period in which the Ritsuryo codes were abolished, the court rank became a rank of honor which was bestowed upon those who had been government officials or those who had performed significant services.

The court rank was designed mainly for princes without the title of Shinno (Imperial Prince), members of the Imperial family, and their subjects, but after the Meiji period in which the Ritsuryo codes were abolished, the court rank became a rank of honor which was bestowed upon those who had been government officials or those who had performed significant services.

sen.j: 今日においても日本国憲法に基づく栄典のひとつされ、毎年功労ある物故者に授けられている。
sen.e: At present, it is also a rank of honor under the Constitution of Japan, which is bestowed every year upon the deceased who have done distinguished services.
At present, it is also a rank of honor under the Constitution of Japan, which is bestowed every year upon the deceased who have done distinguished services.
At present, it is also a rank of honor under the Constitution of Japan, which is bestowed every year upon the deceased who have done distinguished services.

sen.j: なお、位階に叙すことを叙位（じょい）と言い、平安時代以後は、宮中で五位以上の位階を授ける儀式（正月五日頃に行われる。）のことも叙位と言った。
sen.e: In addition, the conferment of a court rank is called "Joi," and the ceremony held in the Imperial Court in which the Fifth Court Rank and above are granted is also called "Joi" after the Heian period. (It is held on around January 5.)

In addition, the conferment of a court rank is called "Joi," and the ceremony held in the Imperial Court in which the Fifth Court Rank and above are granted is also called "Joi" after the Heian period. (It is held on around January 5.)

In addition, the conferment of a court rank is called "Joi," and the ceremony held in the Imperial Court in which the Fifth Rank and above are granted is also called "Joi" after the Heian period. (It is held on around January 5.).

sen.j: また、位階と混同して用いられることの多い「官位」とは「官職と位階」を指し、位階とは異なる。
sen.e: "Kani" (the official rank), which is often confused with the court rank, is referred to as "the official post and rank" and differs from Ikai (the court rank).
"Kani" (the official rank), which is often confused with the court rank, is referred to as "the official post and rank" and differs from Ikai (the court rank).
"Kani" (the official rank), which is often confused with the court rank, is referred to as "the official post and rank" and differs from Ikai.
sen.cmt: 既出のため最後の括弧書きを削除

tit.e: The Japanese court rank system
The Japanese court rank system
The Japanese court rank system

sen.j: 位階制度は、他の政治行政制度と共に中国から継受し、日本で独自の発展を遂げた。
sen.e: The court rank system introduced from China with other political and administrative systems has developed independently in Japan.
The court rank system introduced from China with other political and administrative systems has developed independently in Japan.
The court rank system introduced from China with other political and administrative systems has developed independently in Japan.

sen.j: 初めて官吏を序列付けたのは、603年（推古天皇11年）の冠位十二階である。
sen.e: The Twelve-cap court rank system established in 603 was the first that imposed a ranking among government officials.
The Twelve-cap court rank system established in 603 was the first that imposed a ranking among government officials.
The Twelve-cap court rank system established in 603 was the first that imposed a ranking among government officials.

sen.j: その後数度の変遷を経て（→冠位・官位制度の変遷）、701年（大宝 (日本)元年）の大宝律令および718年（養老2年）の養老律令によって位階制度の基本が固まった。
sen.e: After several changes (see The changes in the court and the official ranks), the foundation of the court rank system was established under the Taiho (701) and the Yoro (718) codes.
sen.cmt: 「冠位・官位制度の変遷」の定訳がわかりませんが、このようにしました。
sen.e: After several changes (see The changes in the court and the official ranks), the foundation of the court rank system was established under the Taiho (701) and the Yoro (718) codes.
After several changes (see The changes in the court and the official ranks), the foundation of the court rank system was established under the Taiho (701) and the Yoro (718) codes.

sen.j: 673年以降は神にも位階が与えられた（神階参照）。
sen.e: After 673, even gods were given ranks (see The rank of Gods).
sen.cmt: 「神階」の定訳がわかりませんが、このようにしました。
sen.e: After 673, even gods were given ranks (see The rank of Gods).
After 673, even gods were given ranks (see Shinkai, ranks granted to Shinto gods).

tit.e: The court rank system under the Ritsuryo codes
The court rank system under the Ritsuryo codes
The court rank system under the Ritsuryo System.
Summary
Summary
Summary

sen.j: 位階制度は、位階と官職を関連づけることにより（官位制）、血縁や勢力にとらわれず適材適所を配置し、官職の世襲を防いだ。
sen.e: By connecting the court rank with the official post (the official rank system), the court rank system placed the right person in the right post regardless of heredity or power, and also avoided the hereditary transfer of the official post.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: By connecting the court rank with the official post (the official rank system), the court rank system placed the right person in the right post regardless of heredity or power, and also avoided the hereditary transfer of the official post.

By connecting the court rank with the official post (the official rank system), the court rank system placed the right person in the right post regardless of heredity or power, and also avoided the hereditary transfer of the official post.

sen.j: また、天皇が位階を授与することで、全ての権威と権力を天皇に集中し、天皇を頂点とした国家体制の確立を目的とした。
sen.e: The system that the Emperor imposed a court rank also concentrated the authority and power in the hands of the Emperor, which led to the establishment of the political system that placed the Emperor at the top.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The system that the Emperor used to impose a court rank also concentrated the authority and power in the hands of the Emperor, which led to the establishment of the political system that placed the Emperor at the top.

The system that the Emperor used to impose a court rank also concentrated the authority and power in the hands of the Emperor, which led to the establishment of the political system that placed the Emperor at the top.

sen.j: 大宝令・養老令のうち官位について定めた『官位令』によれば、皇族の親王は一品（いっぽん）から四品（しほん）までの4階、諸王は正一位から従五位下まで14階、臣下は正一位から少初位下（しょうそいげ）まで30階の位階がある。
sen.e: According to "Kani rei" 官位令 (the law concerning the official rank) of the Taiho and the Yoro Ritsuryo codes, the Imperial princes of the Imperial family were graded in four ranks from "Ippon" to "Shihon" (First to Fourth Rank); other princes without the title of "Shinno" (Prince of the blood) were in fourteen ranks from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade); subjects were in thirty ranks from Shoichii to Shosoige (Lesser Initial Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 「官位令」の定訳について、国会図書館議会官庁資料室等、日本法令外国語訳データベースなどであたりましたが見つかりませんでした。
sen.e: According to "Kani rei" 官位令 (the law concerning the official rank) of the Taiho and the Yoro Ritsuryo codes, the Imperial princes of the Imperial family were graded in four ranks from "Ippon" to "Shihon" (First to Fourth Rank); other princes without the title of "Shinno" (Prince of the blood) were in fourteen ranks from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade); subjects were in thirty ranks from Shoichii to Shosoige (Lesser Initial Rank, Lower Grade).

According to "Kani rei" 官位令 (the law concerning the official rank) of the Taiho and the Yoro Ritsuryo codes, the Imperial princes of the Imperial family were graded in four ranks from "Ippon" to "Shihon" (First to Fourth Rank); other Shoo (princes who didn't receive any proclamation to be an Imperial Prince) were in fourteen ranks from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Jugoinoge (Junior Fifth Rank, Lower Grade); subjects were in thirty ranks from Shoichii to Shosoige (Lesser Initial Rank, Lower Grade).
sen.cmt: 諸王を "Shoo (princes who didn't receive any proclamation to be an Imperial Prince)" としました。

sen.j: 位階によって就くことのできる官職が定まり、位階に応じて衣類などにも制限が加えられる。
sen.e: The official post was determined by the court rank, and restrictions on costumes were imposed according to the court rank.
The official post was determined by the court rank, and restrictions on costumes were imposed according to the court rank.
The official post was determined by the court rank, and restrictions on costumes were imposed according to the court rank.

sen.j: また、五位以上の者には位田が支給される規定となっていた。
sen.e: It was stipulated that those who ｗere of Fifth Rank and above were provided with "Iden" (rice fields provided depending on the court rank).
It was stipulated that those who ｗere of Fifth Rank and above were provided with "Iden" (rice fields provided depending on the court rank).
It was stipulated that those who ｗere of Fifth Rank and above were provided with "Iden" (rice fields provided depending on the court rank).

sen.j: なお、律令制における「貴族」とは五位以上の者を指し、これには昇殿などの特権が与えられた。
sen.e: Under the Ritsuryo codes,"the nobility" were referred to as persons of Fifth Rank or higher, and granted the privilege of stepping into the Seiryo den (Palace Hall).
Under the Ritsuryo codes, "the nobility" were referred to as persons of Fifth Rank or higher, and granted the privilege of stepping into the Seiryo den (Palace Hall).
Under the Ritsuryo System, 'the nobility' were referred to as persons of Fifth Rank or higher, and granted the privilege of stepping into the Imperial Court.
sen.cmt: 律令制の翻訳を変更Seiryo den→the Imperial Court としました。

sen.j: 「貴族」に対し、六位以下無位までの者を「地下」（ぢげ）もしくは「地下人」と呼ぶ。
sen.e: In contrast to "the nobility," those who were of Sixth Rank or lower to no rank were called "Jige" or "Jigenin" (those who were not allowed to enter the Seiryo den).
In contrast to "the nobility," those who were of Sixth Rank or lower to no rank were called "Jige" or "Jigenin" (those who were not allowed to enter the Seiryo den).
In contrast to 'the nobility,' those who were of Sixth Rank or lower to no rank were called 'Jige' or 'Jigenin.'
sen.cmt: 「地下」、「地下人」の説明行っている文書なので英語での説明は不要と理解しました。

sen.j: 朝廷及び明治新政府では、故人に対して生前の功績を称え位階または官職を追贈がなされることがあった。
sen.e: Under the Imperial Court and the new Meiji government, the court rank and the official post were conferred on the deceased in the recognition of the services done in their lifetime.
Under the Imperial Court and the new Meiji government, the court rank and the official post were conferred on the deceased in the recognition of services done in their lifetime.
Under the Imperial Court and the new Meiji government, the court rank and the official post were conferred on the deceased in the recognition of services done in their lifetime.

sen.j: 位階を贈ることを贈位、官職を贈ることを贈官といった。
sen.e: The posthumous conferment of the court rank and the official post were called "Zoi" and "Zokan," respectively.
The posthumous conferment of court rank and the official post were called "Zoi" and "Zokan," respectively.
The posthumous conferment of court rank and the official post were called "Zoi" and "Zokan," respectively.

sen.j: (例)贈正四位、(例)贈内大臣。
sen.e: e.g. Shoshii (Senior Fourth Rank, posthumously conferred); Naidaijin (Minister of the center), posthumously conferred

sen.j: 正○位の「正」は「せい」でなく「しょう」、従○位の「従」は「じゅう」でなく「じゅ」と読む。
sen.e: The reading of "正" in "正O位" is not "Sei" but "Sho," and the reading of "従" in "従O位" is not "Juh" but "Ju."
The reading of "正" in "正O位" is not "Sei" but "Sho," and the reading of "従" in "従O位" is not "Juh" but "Ju."
The reading of "正" in "正O位" is not "Sei" but "Sho," and the reading of "従" in "従O位" is not "Juh" but "Ju."

sen.j: また、三位は「さんい」でなく「さんみ」、四位は「よんい」でなく「しい」、七位は「なない」でなく「しちい」と読む。
sen.e: In addition, the reading of "三位" is not "Sani" but "Sanmi,"; "四位" is not "Yoni" but "Shii"; "七位" is not "Nanai" but "Shichii."
In addition, the reading of "三位" is not "Sani" but "Sanmi,"; "四位" is not "Yoni" but "Shii"; "七位" is not "Nanai" but "Shichii."
In addition, the reading of "三位" is not "Sani" but "Sanmi,"; "四位" is not "Yoni" but "Shii"; "七位" is not "Nanai" but "Shichii."

tit.e: "Oni no sei" (the system of securing court ranks for sons or grandsons of high-ranking nobles)
"Oni no sei" (the system of securing court ranking for sons or grandsons of high-ranking nobles)
"Oni no sei" (the system of securing court ranking for sons or grandsons of high-ranking nobles)

sen.j: 蔭位の制（おんいのせい）とは、高位者の子孫を一定以上の位階に叙位する制度。
sen.e: "Oni no sei" was a system that guranteed a certain level of the court rank for descendants of high-ranking nobles.
"Oni no sei" was a system that guaranteed a certain level of court rank for descendants of high-ranking nobles.
"Oni no sei" was a system that guaranteed a certain level of court rank for descendants of high-ranking nobles.

sen.j: 父祖のお蔭で叙位するの意。
sen.e: It literally means the conferment of the court rank owing to one's ancestors.
It literally means the conferment of the court rank owing to one's ancestors.
It literally means the conferment of the court rank owing to one's ancestors.

sen.j: 令によれば、子孫が21歳以上になったとき叙位され、蔭位資格者は皇親・五世王の子、諸臣三位以上の子と孫、五位以上の子である。
sen.e: According to this law, the court rank was given when the descendants reached the age of twenty one and over; eligible persons for the system of "Oni" were as follows: the children of the Emperor's relatives or princes in the fifth generation, children and grandchildren of sujects of Third Rank or higher, and children of those who were of Fifth Rank or higher.

According to this law, court rank was given when the descendants reached the age of 21 and over; eligible persons for the system of "Oni" were as follows: the children of the Emperor's relatives or princes in the fifth generation, children and grandchildren of subjects of Third Rank or higher, and children of those who were of Fifth Rank or higher.

According to this law, court rank was given when the descendants reached the age of 21 and over; eligible persons for the system of "Oni" were as follows: the children of the Emperor's relatives or princes in the fifth generation, children and grandchildren of subjects of Third Rank or higher, and children of those who were of Fifth Rank or higher.

sen.j: 勲位・贈位も蔭位の適用を受ける。
sen.e: The conferment of the order of merit and the posthumous court rank were applicable to the system of "Oni."
The conferment of the order of merit and the posthumous court rank were applicable to the system of "Oni."
The conferment of the order of merit and the posthumous court rank were applicable to the system of "Oni."

sen.j: 蔭位の制は中国の律令制に倣った制度だが、中国の制度よりも資格者の範囲は狭く、与えられる位階は高い。
sen.e: "Oni no sei," which was based on the Chinese Ritsuryo codes, had a narrow range of qualification, and the rank given was high compared with the Chinese one.
"Oni no sei," which was based on the Chinese Ritsuryo codes, had a narrow range of qualification, and the rank given was high compared with the Chinese one.
"Oni no sei," which was based on the Chinese Ritsuryo System, had a narrow range of qualification, and the rank given was high compared with the Chinese one.

tit.e: Criminal privileges
Criminal privileges
Criminal privileges

sen.j: 儒教の経典である『礼記』には「礼は庶人に下らず、刑は大夫に上らず」とされ、律令法では八虐などによる死罪 (律令法)（実際は流罪及び除名で代替される場合もあった）を例外として、五位以上の官人には実刑を加えないことが原則とされていた。
sen.e: As "Raiki" (the Book of Rites) described that "Rei" (ritual and etiquette) governed the conduct of the nobles while "Kei" (rules of punishment) governed the common people, government officials of Fifth Rank or higher escaped a prison sentence as a rule except the death penalty for eight unpardonable crimes (the Ritsuryo codes). (Actually, the death penalty was substituted with exile or expulsion.)

As "Raiki" (the Book of Rites) described that "Rei" (ritual and etiquette) governed the conduct of the nobles while "Kei" (rules of punishment) governed the common people, government officials of the Fifth Rank or higher, as a rule, escaped a prison sentences except for the death penalty, for eight unpardonable crimes (the Ritsuryo codes). (Actually, the death penalty was substituted with exile or expulsion.)

As "Raiki" (the Book of Rites), which is a Confucian scripture, described that "Rei" (ritual and etiquette) governed the conduct of the nobles while "Kei" (rules of punishment) governed the common people, government officials of the Fifth Rank or higher, as a rule, escaped a prison sentences except for the death penalty, for eight unpardonable crimes (the Ritsuryo codes). (In fact, the death penalty was substituted with exile or expulsion.)
sen.cmt: 「儒教の経典である」を追記"Actually"→"In fact"に変更しました。

sen.j: 日本では中国の八議（『周礼』では八辟）の制度を元にして名例律において六議の制が定められ、三位以上は6番目の「貴」とされて減刑の対象となり、更に五位以上でも「請」の手続を経ることで準用が認められた。
sen.e: In Japan, based on the Chinese "Hachigi"system (the Eight Deliberations) or "Hachiheki"system described in "Shurai" (the Rites of Zhou), "Rikugi no sei " (the Six Deliberations) was established in the "Meireiritsu" (criminal codes); those who were of Third Rank and above received the favor of a lesser punishment as the sixth condition of "Ki" (high officials), and those who were of Fifth Rank and above were also applicable to such a case by taking the procedure of "Sho" (criminal previleges for the nobles).

In Japan, based on the Chinese "Hachigi"system (the Eight Deliberations) or "Hachiheki"system described in "Shurai" (the Rites of Zhou), "Rikugi no sei " (the Six Deliberations) was established in the "Meireiritsu" (criminal codes); those who were of Third Rank and above received the favor of a lesser punishment as the sixth condition of "Ki" (high officials), and those who were of Fifth Rank and above were also applicable to such a case by taking the procedure of "Sho" (criminal previleges for the nobles).

In Japan, based on the Chinese "Hachigi"system (the Eight Deliberations) or "Hachiheki"system described in "Shurai" (the Rites of Zhou), "Rikugi no sei " (the Six Deliberations) was established in the Meirei-ritsu (Japanese criminal law); those who were of Third Rank and above received the favor of a lesser punishment as the sixth condition of "Ki" (high officials), and those who were of Fifth Rank and above were also applicable to such a case by taking the procedure of "Sho" (criminal previleges for the nobles).

sen.j: 流罪以下の刑に処せられた場合、罪一等を減じた上で官当により自らの位記を返上して罪を贖った。
sen.e: When a high-ranking official was sentenced to punishments less than exile, his sentence was always reduced by one degree; he could expiate his crime by giving up his title, that is, "Kanto."
When a high-ranking official was sentenced to punishments less than exile, his sentence was always reduced by one degree; he could expiate his crime by giving up his title, that is, "Kanto."
When a high-ranking official was sentenced to punishments less than exile, his sentence was always reduced by one degree; he could expiate his crime by giving up his title, which is, "Kanto."
sen.cmt: that→which 前文全体を指す場合はwhichだと思います。thatだとtitleを指すことになると思いますが、ご確認願います

sen.j: 平安時代中期においては、官職の重要性が高まったために左遷や解官（官職罷免）による換刑が行われた。
sen.e: The commutation of a punishment by a dismissal of an official post or demotion was common because the official posts became extremely important in the middle Heian period.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The commutation of a punishment by a dismissal of an official post or demotion was common because the official posts became extremely important in the middle Heian period.
The commutation of a punishment by a dismissal of an official post or demotion was common because the official posts became important in the middle Heian period.
sen.cmt: 原文には「非常に」という言葉はありませんが、extremelyは不要と判断しました。

sen.j: 散位や卑官の者に限って官当や贖銅で罪を贖うことで実刑を免れるのが一般的であった。
sen.e: It was also generally accepted that only those who were "Sani" (a person who had the court rank but no official post) or "Hikan" (a person of the lower rank) could escape imprisonment and expiate crimes by giving up official posts or by offering copper coins.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It was also generally accepted that only those who were "Sani" (a person who had the court rank, but no official post) or "Hikan" (a person of the lower rank) could escape imprisonment and expiate crimes by giving up official posts or by offering copper coins.

It was also generally accepted that only those who were Sani (courtier without post) or Hikan (a person of the lower rank) could escape imprisonment and expiate crimes by giving up official posts or by offering copper coins.
sen.cmt: 散位を定訳に変更卑官の" "削除

tit.e: The emasculation of the court rank system
The emasculation of the court rank system
The emasculation of the court rank system

sen.j: 本来は能力によって位階を位置付け、その位階と能力に見合った官職に就けることで、官職の世襲を妨げることを大きな目的とした。
sen.e: The court rank system was originally designed for the purpose of avoiding the hereditary transfer of the official post, setting the court rank based on the ability and giving the appropriate official post for the court rank and ability.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: The court rank system was originally designed for the purpose of avoiding the hereditary transfer of an official post, setting the court rank based on ability and giving the appropriate official post for the court rank and level of ability.

The court rank system was originally designed for the purpose of avoiding the hereditary transfer of an official post, setting the court rank based on ability and giving the appropriate official post for the court rank and level of ability.

sen.j: しかしながら、蔭位の制を設けるなど、世襲制を許す条件を当初から含んでいた。
sen.e: However, it contained such a condition as allowed the hereditary transfer of the official post from the start: the establishment of "Oni no sei" (the system of securing court ranks for sons or grandsons of high-ranking nobles).
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: However, it contained such a condition to allow the hereditary transfer of the official post from the start: the establishment of "Oni no sei" (the system of securing court ranks for sons or grandsons of high-ranking nobles).
However, it contained such a condition to allow the hereditary transfer of the official post from the start: the establishment of "Oni no sei".
sen.cmt: 既出のため最後の括弧書き削除

sen.j: そのため、平安時代の初期には形骸化して一部の上流貴族に世襲的な官職の独占を許すに到った。
sen.e: For all these reasons, the court rank system became an empty formality in the early Heian period, resulting in that some high-ranking nobles monopolized the hereditary transfer of the official post.
For all these reasons, the court rank system became an empty formality in the early Heian period, resulting in that some high-ranking nobles monopolized the hereditary transfer of the official post.
For all these reasons, the court rank system became an empty formality in the early Heian period, resulting in that some high-ranking nobles monopolized the hereditary transfer of the official post.

sen.j: 明治維新により律令法が廃された後も、太政官においては、暫く続けられた（明治2年8月20日 (旧暦)に大少初位の代わりに正九位・従九位が設けられている）。
sen.e: When the Ritsuryo codes were abolished in the Meiji Restoration, the court rank system continued in the Council of State for a while. (Shokyui [Senior Ninth Rank] and Jukyui [Junior Ninth Rank] were established instead of Daishosoi [Greater and Lesser Initial Rank] on August 20 1869 according to the old calendar.)

When the Ritsuryo codes were abolished in the Meiji Restoration, the court rank system continued in the Council of State for a while. (Shokyui [Senior Ninth Rank] and Jukyui [Junior Ninth Rank] were established instead of Daishosoi [Greater and Lesser Initial Rank] on August 20 1869 according to the old calendar.)

When the Ritsuryo codes were abolished in the Meiji Restoration, the court rank system continued in Daijokan (Grand Council of State) for a while. (Shokyui [Senior Ninth Rank] and Jukyui [Junior Ninth Rank] were established instead of Daishosoi [Greater and Lesser Initial Rank] on August 20 1869 according to the old calendar.)

sen.j: 明治4年8月10日 (旧暦)には官等の導入によって一旦は廃止された。
sen.e: On August 10 1871 according to the old calendar, the court rank system was temporarily abolished because of the introduction of "Kanto" (the government official rank system).
On August 10 1871 according to the old calendar, the court rank system was temporarily abolished because of the introduction of "Kanto" (the government official rank system).
On August 10 1871 according to the old calendar, the court rank system was temporarily abolished because of the introduction of "Kanto" (the government official rank system).

sen.j: 1887年（明治20年）には、「叙位条例」（明治20年勅令第10号）が制定されて位階制度が復活した。
sen.e: In 1887, the "Joijorei" (Regulations concerning the Conferment of Court Rank: Imperial Ordinance No.10 1887) was enacted, and the court rank system was restored.
sen.cmt: www.japanesehistory.de-Personal Homepage of Sven Saaler の叙位条例の翻訳を引用しました （この方は研究者のようです）。
sen.e: In 1887, the "Joijorei" (Regulations concerning the Conferment of Court Rank: Imperial Ordinance No.10 1887) was enacted, and the court rank system was restored.
In 1887, the "Joijorei" (Regulations concerning the Conferment of Court Rank: Imperial Ordinance No.10 1887) was enacted, and the court rank system was restored.

sen.j: 叙位条例以降は、正一位から従八位までの16階（叙位条例も同じ）とされた。
sen.e: After the "Joijorei" was enacted, the rank was divided into sixteen grades from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Juhachii (Junior Eighth Rank). (including "Joijorei")
After the "Joijorei" was enacted, the rank was divided into sixteen grades from Shoichii (Senior First Rank) to Juhachii (Junior Eighth Rank). (including "Joijorei")
After the "Joijorei" was enacted, the rank was divided into sixteen grades from Shoichii to Juhachii. (including "Joijorei")

sen.j: 叙位条例によると「凡ソ位ハ華族勅奏任官及国家ニ勲功アル者又ハ表彰スヘキ功績アル者ニ叙ス」（叙位条例第1条）とされた。
sen.e: The "Joijorei" stipulated that "Court rank is conferred on Peers, officials of the "Choku nin" and "So nin"ranks, persons who have rendered distinguished services to the State or persons of such merit as to warrant public notice." (Article 1 of "Joijorei")
sen.cmt: www.japanesehistory.de-Personal Homepage of Sven Saaler の叙位条例の翻訳を引用しました。
sen.e: The "Joijorei" stipulated that "Court rank is conferred on Peers, officials of the "Choku nin" and "So nin"ranks, persons who have rendered distinguished services to the State or persons of such merit as to warrant public notice." (Article 1 of "Joijorei")

The "Joijorei" stipulated that "Court rank is conferred on Peers, officials of the "Choku nin" and "So nin"ranks, persons who have rendered distinguished services to the State or persons of such merit as to warrant public notice." (Article 1 of "Joijorei")

sen.j: 叙位条例によると、従四位以上は勅授（宮内大臣から伝達）、正五位以下は奏授（宮内大臣が天皇に奏して叙位）とされた。
sen.e: According to the "Joijorei," the court rank from Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) upwards was conferred by "Chokuju" (Imperial grace through the Minister of the Imperial Household), and that from the Senior Fifth Rank downwards was conferred with "Soju" (Imperial approval and made public by the Minister of the Imperial Household).
sen.cmt: www.japanesehistory.de-Personal Homepage of Sven Saaler の叙位条例の翻訳を引用しました。
sen.e: According to the "Joijorei," the court rank from Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) upwards was conferred by "Chokuju" (Imperial grace through the Minister of the Imperial Household), and that from the Senior Fifth Rank downwards was conferred with "Soju" (Imperial approval and made public by the Minister of the Imperial Household).

According to the "Joijorei," the court rank from Jushii upwards was conferred by "Chokuju" (Imperial grace through the Minister of the Imperial Household), and that from Shogoi (Senior Fifth Rank) downwards was conferred with "Soju" (Imperial approval and made public by the Minister of the Imperial Household).
sen.cmt: (Junior Fourth Rank) 削除Shogoi を追記して説明を括弧で括りました。Imperial grace がわかりませんでしたのでご確認願います。

sen.j: また位は従四位以上は華族に準じた礼遇を享けた。
sen.e: For the ranks from Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) upwards, treatment was accorded corresponding to Peers.
For the ranks from Jushii (Junior Fourth Rank) upwards, treatment was accorded corresponding to Peers.
For the ranks from Jushii upwards, treatment was accorded corresponding to Peers.

sen.j: 従一位は公爵、正二位は侯爵、正従三位は伯爵、正従四位は男爵に準じた。
sen.e: Persons of Junior First Rank were treated corresponding to the title of Prince; persons of Senior Second Rank, Marquis; persons of Senior and Junior Third Rank, Viscount; and persons of Senior and Junior Fourth Rank, Baron.

Persons of Junior First Rank were treated corresponding to the title of Prince; persons of Senior Second Rank, Marquis; persons of Senior and Junior Third Rank, Viscount; and persons of Senior and Junior Fourth Rank, Baron.

Persons of Juichii (Junior First Rank) were treated corresponding to the title of Prince; persons of Shonii (Senior Second Rank), Marquis; persons of Shosanmi/Jusanmi (Senior/Junior Third Rank), Count; and persons of Shoshii/Jushii, Baron.
sen.cmt: Viscount は子爵で、伯爵は earl か count だと思います。"Junior First Rank"→"Juichii (Junior First Rank)"に変更しました。 "Senior Second Rank"→"Shonii (Senior Second Rank)"に変更しました。"Senior and Junior Third Rank"→"Shosanmi/Jusanmi (Senior/Junior Third Rank)"に変更しました。"Senior and Junior Fourth Rank"→"Shoshii/Jushii"に変更しました。

tit.e: 1926-the end of the war
1926-the end of the war
1926 to the end of the war

sen.j: 1926年（大正15年）には「位階令」（大正15年勅令第325号）が制定された。
sen.e: In 1926, "Ikai rei" 位階令 (the decree concerning the court rank: Imperial Ordinance No. 325 1926) was enacted.
sen.cmt: 「位階令」の定訳を国会図書館議会官庁資料室等で調べましたが見つかりませんでした。
sen.e: In 1926, "Ikai rei" 位階令 (the decree concerning the court rank: Imperial Ordinance No. 325 1926) was enacted.
In 1926, "Ikai rei" 位階令 (the decree concerning the court rank: Imperial Ordinance No. 325 1926) was enacted.

sen.j: これにより、勲章 (日本)・褒章と並ぶ栄典制度の一つとして位階制度は維持されてきた。
sen.e: So, the court rank system was maintained as a system of awarding honors along with the conferment of orders and medals (Japan).
So, the court rank system was maintained as a system of awarding honors along with the conferment of orders and medals (Japan).
So, the court rank system has benn maintained as a system of awarding honors along with the conferment of orders and medals (Japan).
sen.cmt: 「位階制度」は現在も続いているため was→has been としました。

sen.j: 叙勲と異なり、日本国籍を失ったときには位も失い、外国人を叙位することはない。
sen.e: Unlike the conferment of decorations, persons who had lost or abandoned their nationality were deprived of the rank, and foreigners were not entitled to the conferment of court ranks.
Unlike the conferment of decorations, persons who had lost or abandoned their nationality were deprived of the rank, and foreigners were not entitled to the conferment of court ranks.
Unlike the conferment of decorations, persons who has lost or abandoned their nationality are deprived of the rank, and foreigners are not entitled to the conferment of court ranks.

sen.j: また、位階は臣民にのみ与えられ、皇族を叙位することはない（ただし、皇籍を離脱した者は叙位の対象となる）。
sen.e: The court rank was conferred on only civil subjects; the Imperial family were not entitled to the conferment of court ranks. (Those who lost their status as a member of the Imperial family enjoyed the conferment of court ranks.)

The court rank was conferred on only civil subjects; the Imperial family were not entitled to the conferment of court ranks. (Those who lost their status as a member of the Imperial family enjoyed the conferment of court ranks.)

The court rank was conferred on only civil subjects; the Imperial family were not entitled to the conferment of court ranks. (Those who lost their status as a member of the Imperial family enjoyed the conferment of court ranks.)
sen.cmt: 「臣民」は現在は使われていないため過去形のままとしました。

sen.j: 所管は宮内省宗秩寮。
sen.e: "Sochitsuryo" (a bureau of the Minister of the Imperial Household) was a section in charge.
"Sochitsuryo" (a bureau of the Minister of the Imperial Household) was a section in charge.
"Sochitsuryo" (a bureau of the Minister of the Imperial Household) was a section in charge.

sen.j: 位階令では、従来の叙位条例から叙爵対象の順序が変更され、「国家ニ勲功アリ又ハ表彰スヘキ功績アル者」・「有爵者及爵ヲ襲クコトヲ得ヘキ相続人」・「在官者及在職者」とされた。
sen.e: As for the "Ikai rei," the sequential order of eligible persons for the conferment of court ranks in the former "Joijorei" was changed as follows: "Persons who have rendered distinguished services to the State or persons of such merit as to warrant public notice," "Persons who possess the titles of nobility or the legal heir who is entitled to succeed to the titles of nobility," "The holder of a government post and the holder of a position."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処 「国家ニ勲功アリ又ハ表彰スヘキ功績アル者」はwww.japanesehistory.de-Personal Homepage of Sven Saaler から引用
sen.e: As for the "Ikai rei," the sequential order of eligible persons for the conferment of court ranks in the former "Joijorei" was changed as follows: "Persons who have rendered distinguished services to the State or persons of such merit as to warrant public notice," "Persons who possess the titles of nobility or the legal heir who is entitled to succeed to the titles of nobility," "The holder of a government post and the holder of a position."

As for the "Ikai rei," the sequential order of eligible persons for the conferment of court ranks in the former "Joijorei" was changed as follows: "Persons who have rendered distinguished services to the State or persons of such merit as to warrant public notice," "Persons who possess the titles of nobility or the legal heir who is entitled to succeed to the titles of nobility," "The holder of a government post and the holder of a position."

sen.j: 結果的に、栄典制度としての側面をより強調することとなった。
sen.e: Accordingly, the aspect of awarding honors was more emphasized.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Accordingly, the aspect of awarding honors was more emphasized.
Accordingly, the aspect of awarding honors was more emphasized.

sen.j: 位階令によると、正二位以下の授与形態に変更はなかったが、正従一位は特に親授（親授式で、天皇から位記を授与）とされた。
sen.e: The form of conferment from Shonii (Senior Second Rank) downwards was not changed, but Shojuichii (Senior and Junior First Rank) was especially conferred by "Shinju" (personal investiture by the Emperor). (A diploma of court rank was bestowed personally by the Emperor upon the recipiant in the ceremony of Imperial conferment of decoraiton.)

The form of conferment from Shonii (Senior Second Rank) downwards was not changed, but Shojuichii (Senior and Junior First Rank) was especially conferred by "Shinju" (personal investiture by the Emperor). (A diploma of court rank was bestowed personally by the Emperor upon the recipiant in the ceremony of Imperial conferment of decoraiton.)

The form of conferment from Shonii downwards was not changed, but Shoichii/Juichii (Senior/Junior First Rank) was especially conferred by "Shinju" (personal investiture by the Emperor). (A diploma of court rank was bestowed personally by the Emperor upon the recipiant in the ceremony of Imperial conferment of decoraiton.)
sen.cmt: "Shonii (Senior Second Rank)"→"Shonii"に変更しました。"Shojuichii (Senior and Junior First Rank)"→"Shoichii/Juichii (Senior/Junior First Rank)"に変更しました。

tit.e: 1964-Present
1964-Present
1964 to Present

sen.j: 第二次世界大戦後、叙勲と共に叙位は一時停止された。
sen.e: After the Second World War, the conferment of the court rank was suspended for a while along with the conferment of decoration.
After the Second World War, the conferment of court rank was suspended for a while along with the conferment of decoration.
After the Second World War, the conferment of court rank was suspended for a while along with the conferment of decoration.

sen.j: その後、1964年、授与対象を故人に限って復活した。
sen.e: Then, it was restored in 1964, limiting the recipients to the deceased.
Then, it was restored in 1964, limiting the recipients to the deceased.
Then, it was restored in 1964, limiting the recipients to the deceased.

sen.j: そのため現在では、故人の功績を称え、追悼する意味合いが強い。
sen.e: So, at present, it has strong implications of praising and commemorating the achievements done by the deceased.
So, at present, it has strong implications of praising and commemorating the achievements done by the deceased.
So, at present, it has strong implications of praising and commemorating the achievements done by the deceased.

sen.j: 授与に当たっての選考基準は叙勲とほぼ同じだが、細部で異なっており、功績種別によっても選考基準が異なる。
sen.e: The eligibility criteria for the recipients are almost the same as that of the conferment of decoration, but the details differ, such that the eligibility criteria depend on what kind of achievements done.

The eligibility criteria for the recipients are almost the same as that of the conferment of decoration, but the details differ, such that the eligibility criteria depend on what kind of achievements done.

The eligibility criteria for the recipients are almost the same as that of the conferment of decoration, but the details differ, such that the eligibility criteria depend on what kind of achievements done.

sen.j: 叙勲の所管は内閣府賞勲局（中央省庁再編前は総理府賞勲局）、叙位の所管は内閣府大臣官房人事課（中央省庁再編前は内閣総理大臣官房人事課）である。
sen.e: The Cabinet Office Decoration Bureau (the Prime Minister's Office Decoration Bureau before the reorganization of the central government) is a section in charge of the conferment of decoration; the Cabinet Office Minister's Secretariat Personnel Division (Prime Minister's Secretariat Personnel Division before the reorganization of the central government) is a section in charge of the conferment of court rank.

The Cabinet Office Decoration Bureau (the Prime Minister's Office Decoration Bureau before the reorganization of the central government) is a section in charge of the conferment of decoration; the Cabinet Office Minister's Secretariat Personnel Division (Prime Minister's Secretariat Personnel Division before the reorganization of the central government) is a section in charge of the conferment of court rank.

The Cabinet Office Decoration Bureau (the Prime Minister's Office Decoration Bureau before the reorganization of the central government) is a section in charge of the conferment of decoration; the Cabinet Office Minister's Secretariat Personnel Division (Prime Minister's Secretariat Personnel Division before the reorganization of the central government) is a section in charge of the conferment of court rank.

sen.j: 長く公的な職にあった者（議員・官吏・消防吏員・消防団員・教員等々）に叙位される例が多い。
sen.e: Those who served long in public office (members of the Diet, government officials, fire officers, members of a fire brigade, and teachers) are often conferred court ranks.
Those who served long in public office (members of the Diet, government officials, fire officers, members of a fire brigade, and teachers) are often conferred court ranks.
Those who served long in public office (members of the Diet, government officials, fire officers, members of a fire brigade, teachers, etc.) are often conferred court ranks.
sen.cmt: 等々とあるため、and を省いて etc. 追記

sen.j: 叙位された場合、それを証する位記が交付される。
sen.e: A diploma of court rank is issued to certify the conferment of the court rank.
A diploma of court rank is issued to certify the conferment of the court rank.
A diploma of court rank is issued to certify the conferment of the court rank.

sen.j: 位記には縦書きで次のような記載がなされる。
sen.e: The following contents are stated vertically in the diploma of court rank.
The following contents are stated vertically in the diploma of court rank.
The following contents are stated vertically in the diploma of court rank.

sen.e: Persons of Junior Fourth Rank upwards
